greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Least k such that n^k contains all the digits from 0 through 9, or 0 if no such k exists.
comment: Note that the values of n for which a(n) = 1 have density 1.
Is it known that a(n)=0 only for n a power of 10? - _Christopher J. Smyth_, Aug 21 2014
a(n) >= ceiling(log_n(10)*9) (where defined). This is because in order for an integer to have 10 digits its base 10 magnitude must be at least 9. - _Ely Golden_, Sep 06 2017
link: Seiichi Manyama, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000 (terms 1..1000 from T. D. Noe)
Ely Golden, Python program to generate a(n)
formula: a(10^e) = 0; a(m^e) = a(m)/e for e dividing a(m). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Dec 06 2004
mathematica: Table[If[IntegerQ@ Log10[n], 0, SelectFirst[Range[#, # + 100] &@ Ceiling[9 Log[n, 10]], NoneTrue[DigitCount[n^#], # == 0 &] &]], {n, 71}] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Sep 06 2017 *)
program: (PARI) a(n) = if (n == 10^valuation(n, 10), return (0)); k=1; while(#vecsort(digits(n^k),,8)!=10, k++); k; \\ _Michel Marcus_, Aug 20 2014
xref: Exponents of powers of k that contain all ten decimal digits: A130694 (k=2), A236673 (k=3), A284670 (k=5), A284672 (k=7).
results.author: _Amarnath Murthy_, Dec 03 2003
ext: Corrected a(15), a(17), a(38), a(48), a(56) and a(65). (For each of these terms, the only 1 in n^k is the first digit.) - _Jon E. Schoenfield_, Sep 20 2008
